comments.body: You might not need this ClipRRect.  Instead, try applying the shape to the decorations.  I think the blur effect uses the alpha channel to determine where to apply.
ah interesting. I was trying it before but I didn't understand how it worked. I think the modal barrier causes a scoping problem.

This is an odd semantic. Does it not do anything else?

Maybe we should call it "recommended"? Does iOS call it "default"?

Apple seems to use the same wording https://developer.apple.com/ios/human-interface-guidelines/ui-views/alerts/

Renamed to isDefaultAction to be more specific. Renamed isDestructive to isDestructiveAction too for categorisation
Is this for preventing the dialog box from touching the edge of the screen? Just wondering why vertical only.
Yes, it's to keep it inset from the edge.  The dialog has a fixed width, so there's no reason to do it horizontally.

comments.body: Wondering whether we should have a text size aware proportional edge inset. Would this happen commonly?
Yeah, that's probably a good idea.  Here I was just emulating what happens on iOS when the text size increases, and it probably happens other places.

comments.body: I made the change, but for what it's worth, I disagree about the readability.  We're now forcing the reader to parse the 3rd token in the line to interpret intent. I wouldn't say that's an improvement.
I mean, before you had to read the entire comment. This is the same number of words, and about one sixth the number of lines. I'm not sure I really understand why it's harder to read?
Document what this is for
Done.
I would remove the `??`, we should be providing the default localizations anyway.

It looks like `localizations` is always null. Is there any more work that needs to be done to initialize it correctly? Looks like this eventually rolls up to [`inheritFromWidgetOfExactType`](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/packages/flutter/lib/src/widgets/framework.dart#L1925), which should be callable in `build()` from what I can tell.
Ahh you are right - it looks like we do not provide it anywhere yet
Do we need this merge semantics here?
Yes, otherwise the buttons aren't focusable.

comments.body: It appears that `isDefaultAction` can be explicitly set to `null` in the constructor. Could you add an assert to `CupertinoDialogAction`'s constructor to make sure `isDefaultAction` is not null?

On lines 1049 and 1054, add more lines describing their defaulting behavior:

`Defaults to false and cannot be null`

The font size change here (and the one below) looks good to me. It matches what I saw in Xcode too. I'm not sure how the rest of them (height and letterSpacing) are derived. Could you document where these values came from (similar to https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/21302)? This will help other maintainers when they revise these values.
Sure! I've added code comments.
You are saying the values are from the said plugin, but you had to make some adjustments?

Yup, that's right. Some rounding off and visual comparison is needed after deriving values from the plugin. What I got from the plugin: * Title ```dart fontSize: 17, letterSpacing: -0.544, // Rounded up to -0.5 height: 1.2941176470588236, // Rounded up to 1.3 ``` * Content ```dart fontSize: 13, letterSpacing: -0.10400000000000001, height: 1.2307692307692308, ``` The title `TextStyle` is okay, but content `TextStyle` needed adjustments. When rounded `letterSpacing` and `height` of content to -0.1 and 1.2, the result looks like below. | Before | Native Dialog | Before adjustments | After adjustments | |---|---|---|---| | | | | | So by comparing visually, I updated the content `letterSpacing` and `height` to -0.2 and 1.35.
